testimony:
That is on page 17 or 13?  13 yes?  Very well.  Sorry, could we just swop around?
	Yes, Mr Mtsweni, please stand.  Are you Speelman Ernest Mtsweni?
Thank you, please sit down.  Yes, Mr Richard?
Thank you Mr Chairperson.  Before we get into the details, may I ask you the following question, what is your relationship to the last witness, that is Phillip Mtsweni?
Could you describe exactly who he is married to, is it one of your mother's sisters or is he your father's brother?
He is my uncle because his father is my grandfather.  He is my relative, I don't know clearly to indicate the line of relationship, but he is my relative.
Thank you.  What is your relationship to July Mtsweni?
In other words you share the same mother and father?
Yes, we share the same parents.
Thank you.  So - now during the period 1990/1991 did you belong to any political organisation or support any political organisation?
Yes, I was a follower of the ANC.
For how long had you followed the ANC?  From when did you start?
Even though I wouldn't be able to give you the year, but since I started becoming aware, the ANC was the only organisation, therefore I supported the ANC.
Now, where did you grow up and where were you educated?
Pieterskraal, and I also went to school in Pieterskraal.

Thank you.  Do you agree with the description of Pieterskraal by the previous two witnesses, that it is a rural area, part of the old kwaNdebele which was still then under the influence of tribal leaders and (indistinct) and chiefs?
Now, how did you demonstrate your support and association with the ANC?

The meetings which were held,I used to be one of the people present in the meeting.  Whenever there were consumer boycotts, I used to support that, whenever there were strikes, I used to participate as well.

Thank you.  Now, you have heard the previous witnesses describe a number of events which culminated in the killing of Emma Mtsweni on the 2nd of January 1991, at what stage in those events, did you become connected with what developed?  Was it the 2nd, the 1st, before then?  Which meetings were you at?

I arrived at the school after the meeting had been finished.  It was when they were on their way to the mountains.  Phillip and July dropped other comrades who were in their bakkies.  We got inside the forest with this person.
	When we arrived in the forest, she was questioned as to who else was involved in her work.
If I understand you correctly, Phillip and July Mtsweni came back to the school with her and it was from there that you went to the forest?
I met them in the school after the meeting, as they were going to the mountain.
Thank you.  Now, did you know anything about the story of Emma Mtsweni asking your brother and uncle who had named her, sorry, why they had named her as a witch, did you know any of this background?

What I can say is that when she came and claimed that it had been alleged that she was a witch and she had said that we were the ones who accused her of witchcraft and when she was asked as to who told her that, she didn't want to reveal.  I left the whole story to the elderly because I was still young at that time, so therefore I didn't pursue it.
And you weren't at any of the meetings where that was discussed and decisions were made to refer the problem to an Ngaka and so on?
At the time that you were at the school and people were going to take Emma Mtsweni to the mountain, what did you think they were going to do with her there?
When I arrived at the school, the meeting was over and I did question some of the people there and I was told that they were just going to question her in the mountain.
What were they going to, let me start again, who did you ask that question?
The person who was closer to me, it was Richard Skosana.
Did Richard Skosana belong to or support any political organisation?
Yes, he was, and that is why he was there, he was a supporter of the ANC.
Were there any people there who were not supporters of the ANC?
I would by lying, I think the people who were there, they were supporters of the ANC.
Now, when you got to the mountain, what did they do to Emma Mtsweni?

When we arrived at the mountain, Emma was questioned and what she said was she wasn't in this thing alone.  She also said that the muti that she gave them, she wasn't killing them, she wanted them to be made, the muti was just to make them crazy and she also said that she was working with Mahlangu.  When she said so, Sam Mahlangu who is a son of Mr Mahlangu, said that we must go and fetch his father as well, so that he can come and listen to the allegations.  As Sam went to fetch his father, Victor Ntuli gave the five litre container to Janya.  Janya poured the petrol over Emma and Richard Skosana came and he also poured the petrol over Emma.  I took the petrol from Richard and I also poured.
Now what did the comrades, that you were part of, believe about a person called a moloi?  What did they believe should be done to a moloi?
We believed that the witch or moloi, is the person to be killed.
Why did you believe that a witch should be killed?
It was part of the struggle.  We didn't need witches because we saw them as evil and as obstacles to the development.
In what way was a witch an obstacle to development?
A witch was dangerous.  If we had to leave a witch amongst the community, a witch can destroy the community because he is an obstruction to development.
Do you believe that witches use their magic sorcery against the ANC?
Yes, I do believe because one of the things that a witch can do, is to disrupt development and the witches didn't like what the Youth was doing, and the Youth was fighting the struggle.
Why do you think a witch might have wanted to kill your parents?
Would you please repeat your question?
You are the brother of the first applicant, July Mtsweni?
Now my next question is, your parents had died recently within a short period from each other, is that not correct?
Now my next question is, why  do you think a witch might have wanted your parents dead?
I didn't think that a witch wanted my parents dead.
And when you heard Emma Mtsweni say what she said on the side of the mountain, what did you think?

It was too difficult for me, because first she is the one who came to my home and accused us of accusing her of being a witch and now at the mountain, she was confessing that she had done that, and she was doing it with other people as well.
Who decided that she should die?
Did you hear either of them say that Emma Mtsweni should die?
After she had confessed as to what she had done and who else was involved, one of them said "since she had said so, she must be killed."
How far away from that person, were you when you heard him say that?
Close to me and Emma, this person was closer to me and Emma.
Now, at that stage, did you see Johannes Mahlangu or Charles Skosana near you?
No, I didn't see Johannes.  I saw Charles.
How far away from you, was he?
Charles was closer to me.   I was closer to Charles.

After we had poured the petrol, I didn't see the person who lit the match, but Janya said "Charles, were is the match" and Charles took the box of matches and said "here".  When he said so, a Police van were approaching and the  lights were direct to where we were and I looked at those lights and when I turned back, the body was already on fire but I didn't see the person who actually lit, but the box of matches was with Charles.
Now, on the mountain, were people singing, toyi-toying?
Yes, they were singing and they were toyi-toying.
What were they saying, what were the words of the songs?
What does that mean to you?
It means if you don't come out with the truth, you will be burnt.
Now, what did your age brothers, your comrades, believe are impimpi's and moloi's?
If it had been an impimpi on the mountain, would they have sung any different song?
They will sing the very song and other songs as well, because there are quite a number of songs.
Were any other songs sung before Emma was set on fire?
(Indistinct), meaning an informer is not required, it is banned.
Why did you see, yourself personally, Emma Mtsweni's killing as political?
As we as comrades knew that informers and witches were not needed in the community and on top of that, on that particular day we had leaders amongst us, they are the ones who sanctioned the actions.
How would that further the cause of the liberation struggle?
Would you please repeat your question?
How would the killing of Emma Mtsweni further the freedom struggle, the liberation struggle?
As he or as she had confessed that she was doing that, other witches were going to be scared to do the same and therefore development was going to ensue.

No further questions.
NO FURTHER QUESTIONS BY MR RICHARD
Yes, thank you Mr Richard.  Mr Mokoena?

Thank you Chairperson, I have no questions.
NO CROSS-EXAMINATION BY MR MOKOENA
Thank you Mr Mokoena.  Ms Mtanga, any questions?

I have no questions, Chairperson.
NO CROSS-EXAMINATION BY MS MTANGA
Thank you Ms Mtanga.  Does the Panel have any questions?
Yes, just maybe one or two.  On the way to the mountain, did Emma try to do anything to free herself and perhaps run away?
No, she didn't try on our way to the mountain.
You have said that she was questioned at the mountain.  Who was questioning her?

He questioned her about her running away and he wanted to know why she was running away and she answered back that the reason she ran away was because she had done that and she wasn't alone and also that her motive was not killing my parents, but it was to make them crazy.
What I want to know is did Victor Ntuli use any physical force  to question her?
No, she was not assaulted, she was just questioned.
Was he carrying anything in his hand or hands whilst he was questioning her?
Yes, he had something in his hand, it was the container, the five litre container of petrol.
Then she made what you refer to as the confession that she was a witch?
Victor didn't touch her, he questioned her and she said "yes, I have done that but my aim was not to kill them, but was just to make them crazy."
Did anything happen to the person whose name she mentioned, did anything happen to that person, the one who was said to have given her the muti?
Could you please repeat the question?

You have mentioned a name, I think  you have said it was Mahlangu who supplied the medicine, the muti.  what happened to Mahlangu, did anything happen to him?  You said the group went out to fetch him?
After the group had left, immediately a Police van came.
So is it today the position that nothing ever happened to Mahlangu?

I understood the first two applicants to say that it was dark at the mountain, where were you able to see these people you mentioned, you said, you mentioned a number of names of people who were there at the mountain?  It was dark but you were still able to see these people, or was it not so dark that you could not see them?
Yes, it was dark, but we were together, they were just next to me, close.
Now, Victor Ntuli, do you know if he occupied any portfolio in the ANC or any political organisation aligned with the ANC?
What I can say is that I am not certain about his position but he was a comrade.
Yes, but would you be able to rate him at the same rank as Scwadi and Skosh?  Would he have been of about the same rank in the organisation or was he just an ordinary ANC supporter?
Did you see Scwadi and Skosh at the mountain?
What did they do or what did they say?
They said "since she had confessed, then we must finish with her."
Thank you.  Thank you Mr Chairman.

Mr Mtsweni, on page 15, when you were answering question 10(a) you said there is no political objective to be achieved on this matter, since it is very painful.  My question is did you misunderstand the question or at the time you were completing the form, you believed that there was no political objective to be achieved?
Would you please repeat your question?
Let me maybe rephrase the question.  Did you complete the form on your own, or did somebody help you to complete the form?
I did it on my own.

Can you look at page 15, it says there is no political objective to be achieved.  Did you misunderstand what you were asked or at that stage you believed there was no political objective to be achieved?
I made a mistake when filling in the application.
Thank you, no further questions Chairperson.
With your permission, if I could just take that one further.  What exactly were you trying to say there, if you say you made a mistake?
I made a mistake, I think I didn't quite follow.
In answer to a question raised under 10(b) you seem to regret that this thing was joined by comrades who caused a lot of destruction in the matter, under 10(b)?  Can you show your man, Mr Richard?
Yes, initially this woman came to my home and this matter was a family matter and then later it went on until the comrades were involved.
Thank you.  Thank you Mr Chairman for your indulgence.
One or two questions Mr Chairman.
At what stage did you change your mind and believed that the comrades were right about your grandmother?
Would you please repeat your question?
What you have said so far is initially you thought it was a family matter, but then at some stage you changed your mind.  My question is at what stage, when, did you change your mind?
After I heard that there were comrades who were going to come and burn down my house.

Thank you, no further questions.
NO FURTHER QUESTIONS BY MR RICHARD

Thank you.  Mr Mtsweni, you are excused.
WITNESS EXCUSED
Thank you Chair.  My next person I beg leave to call is Mr Mahlangu.
